Black Fox

Jan 29, 2008

Note: The subject of this poem is place in the Black Hills of South Dakota I used to camp every year as a child.   Black Fox Campground.

My father is packing;
it’s part of his ritual.
A way, perhaps, of mentally washing
the rigors of life’s prisons away.
Prisons on high hills, made pink from Dells quartz
hold purses, not dreams nor ambitions.

Near is the time for Black Fox once more.
Time for crystal streams which go by
the name Rapid.
Time for fireflies to stage their ballet
in coolness of the impending dusk
as a doe bows her head in hunger, in prayer.
Time for trout of one year,
to pause, frozen beneath their hidden waterfall.
They are strangers here too.
Borrowing time, far from the tank of their birth.
We trespass together, invaders and protectors alike.

He lifts an old tent, one of faded green canvas.
Which long ago gave way to nylon expansion.
It still rides along,  a friend of many years,
filled once with memories, even marriages
it has long since grown out of:
Peeking out in pajamas, frozen dew fresh
from the cold before dawn.
It’s scent speaks of moments ago;
coffee forged on a fire,
cakes assembled on iron,
packing still wet as time stood expired.

I think that this year I may climb a small mountain
and sleep alone without sleeping a wink.
I’ll listen for bears, wolves, things which may frighten.
Prone at the summit, with ears to the valley
as my creek sings it’s lullaby to adolescence, adventure.
